moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. c4: One of my favourite openings. I play it often when I am white.
moves.2... d5: Now its called the queens pawn game. I had never seen this move before, but I tried something. (and I thought according to the chess database it is a good move, but that was a mistake, I picked out the best move for white and not the best move for black)
moves.3. Nc3 dxc4: Here the same mistake, I picked out thje most favourable move for white instead of for black.
moves.4. e4 e5: This is better. This move is favourable for black, according to chess database.
moves.5. Nf3: not most common, but the best move as well, according to chess database
moves.5... exd4: making pawn offer and preparing queen offer
moves.7. Nxd4: end of the queen offer, favourable for white
moves.8... O-O: Here is the favour exactly equal for both men.
moves.9... Bxc3+: c6 and Bd7 are both once played on gameknot, but I choosed to offer my bishop for the knight.
moves.12... Ne5: making knight active and he must run away with his bishop.
moves.17. Rfd1: challenges for a offer. When I should accept, he should have a rook on the open line d and I should have a rook on the not-open line f.
moves.18. Kxe2: and give the bishop, he has defended the knight 2 moves ago with the king.
moves.18... c4: attacking the bishop, which is pinning the pawn at f2
moves.21. Rd4: attack the undefended pawn, while defended by his pawn.
moves.22. cxd4: ...and give my rook, what makes that I dont loos material points and creates a little space for my pawn at the line c.
moves.23... Ne7: preparing putting the king in check and offering a pawn
moves.24. Rd1: defending the pawn for the second time and making the rook more active.
moves.25. e5: declining the offer and putting the pawn in the defence of the other pawn.
moves.27. gxf4: This time he accepts the pawn offer
moves.27... Nxf4: and of course I complete the offer.
moves.30. Ke3: defending for the second time the pawn that is attacked for the second time.
moves.31. Rh4: running away and blocking the pawn
moves.31... Kg7: preventing putting in chess, when I takes the undefended pawn.
moves.32. d5: attacking the knight, but I think it was a blunder, for the pawn is out of his defending in this way.
moves.33. Rxh5: and he takes my undefended pawn
moves.33... Rb5: I dont remember exactly, maybe preparing attack at the bishop??
moves.34... Ra5: and I attack the undefended pawn
moves.35. a4: and he puts the pawn in defence of the bishop
moves.35... Nd4: making a fork between bishop and undefended pawn
moves.36. Bd1: running away with bishop and defending the pawn
moves.36... Rd5: it looks like I want create a double-check and he shall want to prevent
moves.37. Kc1: in this way he is preventing that double-check
moves.39... Nxd4: completing the rook offer of course
moves.40. Kd2: first step to do an attack with the king
moves.41... axb5: completing pawn offer(better pawn position than a move ago, they are defending each other now)
moves.43... Ne3: attacking the bishop to delete his concentration on the pawn
moves.44. Be2: running away and attacking the other pawn
moves.44... Kh6: preparing giving support and taking a undefended pawn
moves.45... c3: quickly run forward with the other pawn to promote in a few moves maybe
moves.46... Kg5: preparing giving support and taking a undefended pawn
moves.47. Kc5: giving support too and wants to take that pawn??
moves.50. Bxc2: take the pawn to prevent promoting
moves.50... Nxc2: tajke the bishop, to have a material gain of  2. The first tiome there is a material gain for one of the opponents.
moves.51. f4+: when I take the pawn, I cannot prevent with the king the promote of the pawn
moves.51... Kf5: I dont do that, I block the pawn
moves.53. Ke7: attacking the pawn, that is undefended
moves.53... f6: putting pawn in defence of the king
moves.54. Kf7: This is the greatest blunder ever made I think!! It isnt useful anyway and deletes his only winning chanche!!! You shall see!!
moves.55. h6: running in the race against the clock for promoting
moves.56... Ng6:
but when he runs further, he is taken by me knight. The knight cannot be taken anyway, for he is defended by the king. Therefor he resigned.
You see he is one move too late. When he was 1 move earlier, I had loosed the game. So I want to say move 54 was a blunder. When he had skipped that move he had the victory.
Thabnks for reading his.
